array.string: Welcome to Little AI!
Tap the "commands" (white circles at the bottom of the screen). You may keep this information window open at the same time.
Reach the score of 10 (displayed on the upper left of the game window). Your score is the sum of the values produced by your last ten commands.
The commands generate "events" of interaction between the robot and its environment (small shapes that move up).
On each level, reach the score of 10. Next, follow Little AI's recommendations: press the "gears" to watch the effects of the commands, and the "podium" to see the leaderboard.
Drag the robot to the left or to the right to shift levels.
Imagine that the robot finds the events that have a positive value enjoyable, and those that have a negative value unpleasant.
Generate a sequence of enjoyable events.

Tap an event to replay the same command. The same command replayed in the same context yields the same event. To replay an entire sequence, repeatedly tap the "next command" (white shape that appears on the left when you tap an event).
Press and hold a command to change its shape.
Press and hold an event to change its color.
Change the shapes of commands and the colors of events to recognize them. Shapes and colors are purely descriptive. They do not change the robot.
In the world of Level 4, the robot cannot always avoid unpleasant events.
Generate a sequence that contains as few unpleasant events as possible.
Use different shapes for the commands. Display the enjoyable events in green and the unpleasant events in red. Don't think too much, your brain will see the pattern before you know it!
Experiment with each command individually several times in a raw. One of the commands always yields the same events in a given situation. It is a "persistent" command.
The persistent command allows you to observe the situation of the robot without modifying it.
Use the colors of events to identify the situations that afford enjoyable events.
In Level 6, the commands have the same effects as in Level 5, but they have been rearranged in a random order, and are all initially represented by circles.
It is left to you to attribute shapes to commands and colors to events.
Display the events that make you hope for an enjoyable event on the next round in green, and those that let you fear for an unpleasant event in red.
In Level 7, the commands have the same effects as in Levels 5 and 6, but some events have different values.
Tap the events to replay enjoyable sequences in the context when it is possible.
When you replay a sequence, skip the persistent commands to maximize your score.
On Level 8, the commands have the same effects as in Levels 5 to 7.
Now, however, one of the commands always yields the same events. This command executes a "non-informative action".
Although non-informative actions always yield the same events, do not mistake them for persistent commands.
On level 9, the commands have the same immediate effects as in Levels 5, 6, 7, and 8, but they also transform the environment on the long term.
The robot must transform its environment until it can enact an enjoyable event on every move.
Level 10's world is similar to Level 9's, and events have the same values.
As in Level 8, one of the commands always returns the same type of event (non-informative action).
The robot can move forward and turn in a little box.
This robot loves moving forward but hates bumping into the edges of the box.
The box is even smaller.
Scroll to review the last 100 events. Double-tap on an empty area to scroll back to origin.
Press the score to see your number of moves.
Level 13 offers the same commands as Levels 11 and 12 plus a command that allows the robot to observe its situation without modifying it (persistent command).
This robot hates bumping, and quite dislikes turning. Fortunately, the box is getting bigger!
Use the persistent experiment to avoid bumping into the edges.
Level 14's world is the same as Level 13's.
You are in an analogous situation as a newborn baby that ignores the signification of its gestures and of its senses, or of a robot that ignores the signification of its actuators and sensors.
You must learn to know yourself and your environment to live a happy life!
The robot has two additional commands that it can use to feel the edges around it.
Use these two commands to avoid turning towards the edges.
The box is getting even bigger.
You are in the same world as in Level 15 with the same commands initially uninterpreted.

You reached the last level ! Congratulations! It is similar to Level 16.
